docs.title: Connections
docs.text:
Welcome to Connections, an interactive resource for exploring biblical people, places, tribes, and themes. This project visualizes relationships across the Bible and related sources, providing a rich reference for pastors, scholars, and curious readers alike.

Connections was created by a software engineer with a passion for biblical studies. It applies network and graph theory to connect ideas, themes, people, and places, offering both intuitive exploration and scholarly depth.

docs.title: Quick Start
docs.text:
🎲 Go to Random Page

Explore a randomly selected person, place, theme, or concept from the biblical connections database. Or start with Bethlehem, Rahab, barley, or Jesus to see how it works!

docs.title: What Connections Does
docs.text:
• Maps biblical relationships: who is connected to whom, familial lineages, tribal affiliations, and thematic links.
  • Each page includes references, notes, and visualizations showing its connections to other pages.
  • Includes Old Testament, New Testament, and extra-biblical references for every page.
  • Highlights strong and weak connections to help identify important links and scholarly debates.
  • Supports modular expansion: new pages, connections, or categories can be added via structured data (YAML) files.

docs.title: Browsing
docs.text:
• Search for primary agents like People, Places, Tribes, and Themes using the search bar.
  • Click on a page to view detailed information, references, notes, and visualizations of its connections.

docs.title: References
docs.text:
• Biblical references link to authoritative sources (BibleHub).
  • Academic and extra-biblical references are listed for further study.

docs.title: Visualizations
docs.text:
• Each page may include charts showing connections (family, groups, themes).
  • Charts are generated from the underlying data, so new pages automatically appear.

docs.title: About Us
docs.text:
Welcome! I'm the creator and maintainer of White Tree Bible—a project built (so far) from scratch by a single software engineering manager (and dad of four) living in Boise, Idaho.

I grew up as an aviation missionary kid in Indonesia, attended school in Malaysia, and moved to the U.S. for college. My lifelong love for the Bible, combined with inspiration from the Bible Project (Tim Mackie), led me to pursue a master's degree in Biblical Exposition (hopefully graduating in Fall 2025).

This site is a labor of love, built on nights and weekends, aiming to help others explore the rich connections between people, places, and themes in the Bible. I hope it inspires curiosity, deeper study, and a sense of wonder at the biblical story. May your life advance in every way as you delight in the instruction of Yahweh day and night!

Thank you for visiting and being part of this journey!

docs.title: Contributing
docs.text: Thank you for your interest in contributing! Connections is a collaborative project to map biblical figures, tribes, places, and themes. Contributions follow a clear workflow to ensure data integrity.

docs.title: Financial Contributors
docs.text: Someday, I would love to spend more than a few hours here or there on nights and weekends contributing to this project, but my day-job is still a big part of my life. Once I setup a way to donate, I'll have a way to track if this is a project that can be supported by my full-time work. I'll keep you posted.

docs.title: Academic Contributors
docs.text: As a Bible enthusiast, I hope that others who love to study the Bible want to contribute to this (rather large) potential body of work! I welcome emails and

docs.title: Software Dev Contributors
docs.text:
We welcome contributions! To add new pages or update connections:

  1. Create or modify YAML files in the data/ folder.
  2. Run the build script to generate updated Markdown pages.
  3. Submit a pull request to the repository for review.

For more details, see out contribution guidelines

  1. Clone or fork the repo
git clone https://github.com/whitetreebible/connections.git
cd connections
  1. Install dependencies If you don't have it, install UV first
source .venv/bin/activate
  1. Serve the web
tom yaml
tom serve
  1. Submit a Pull Request:
  2. Make sure all YAML is validated (see scripts/validate_yaml.py).1

  3. PR should include new nodes or updates; generated Markdown will be reviewed automatically.

  4. Deploy the web

tom deploy
  • This will build the static site and push it to the gh-pages branch where Github Pages is serving.

docs.title: Workflow
docs.text:
graph LR;

Bible --> Yaml
Resources --> Yaml
Books --> Yaml

Yaml -->|Ingestion| SQLite
Yaml --> Generators
SQLite --> Generators

Generators --> Markdown

Markdown --> MkDocs

  1. Doesn't exist yet, but someday it will. ↩

docs.title: Project Status
docs.text: Hey, you found the project status page... you must be interested beyond the typical user--welcome!

docs.title: Phase 1: POC
docs.text:
• Completed 2025-09-04 (ish)
  • Demonstrate the graphs in a manual way that seemed promising!

docs.title: Phase 2: Core Build
docs.text:
• Completed 2025-09-13
  • refactor/rename/rebuild so it's scalable/testable/usable - done!
  • nice to haves:
  • transition away from makefile, I need a better script runner framework - done 2025-09-12
  • move static files to their own location so a clean build can be done more simply and comprehensively - done 2025-09-13
  • identify a good way to add incrementally instead of rebuilding everything. versions on nodes? - punt
  • create a way to heal/suggest missing reciprocal links - punt

docs.title: Phase 3: Import Ruth
docs.text:
• In progress
  • all of Ruth links--mostly by hand according to defined categories
  • While it is far slower to do by hand. I'm already coming away with fresh insights from the first chapter of Ruth. For example, I always thought Elimelech's kids married before he died and then they all died over time, but it looks like he died then Naomi arranged marriages for his sons to foreign women. Also, it looks like Ruth and Orpah may have been infertile--which would put Ruth into a whole pattern of miraculous conceptions. Maybe there's something to the by-hand method--however slow that maybe.
  • this does not include any academic resources, just Bible

docs.title: Phase 4: Torah
docs.text:
• add subscription/support ability (who knows, maybe this can become a career instead of a weekend project)
  • share with trusted academics/pastors/influencers
  • complete Ge-De

docs.title: Phase 5
docs.text: • See where it goes?

docs.title: God (creator of the heavens)
docs.text: Elohim is used for God in the Hebrew Bible. It is used for both the creator God and for other gods and divine beings. The singular form Eloah is also used, but less frequently. The name Yahweh (often rendered as LORD in English translations) is the personal name of the God of group/israel.

• Blessed bird (Genesis 1:22), sea creature (Genesis 1:22), sea dragon (Genesis 1:22), human (Genesis 1:28)

docs.title: human (created in God's image)
docs.text: Adam means "human" or "humanity" in Hebrew. The term is used in the Bible to refer to the first human created by God, as well as to humanity in general. According to Genesis 1:26-27, humans were created in the image of God, which signifies a special status and relationship with the divine. This concept is foundational in Judeo-Christian theology, emphasizing the dignity and worth of every human being. Humans are distinct from other creatures due to their responsibility to steward creation.

docs.text:
• Associated with image of God (Genesis 1:26)
  • Leader of sea creature (Genesis 1:26), bird (Genesis 1:26), livestock (Genesis 1:26), crawlers (Genesis 1:26)
  • Role as ruler (Genesis 1:26)

docs.title: tribe of Judah (descendants of Judah)
docs.text: Judah was the fourth son of Jacob and Leah, and his descendants formed the tribe of Judah, one of the twelve tribes of Israel. The tribe of Judah played a significant role in biblical history, being the tribe from which King David and, according to Christian tradition, Jesus Christ descended. The tribe settled in the southern part of the land of Canaan, which later became known as the Kingdom of Judah after the division of the united monarchy.

docs.title: Moabite (descendants of Lot and his older daughter)
docs.text: The Moabites were descendants of Moab, the son of Lot and his older daughter. They settled in the region east of the Dead Sea, in what is now modern-day Jordan. The Moabites had a complex relationship with the Israelites, often marked by conflict but also by periods of peace and intermarriage, as seen in the story of Ruth, a Moabite woman who became the great-grandmother of King David.

docs.title: lights (of the heavens)
docs.text: The lights in the heavens have been interpreted to be the literal sun, moon and stars as well as the spiritual beings that they represented in the ancient world. They are the only other creature given authority to rule in the Genesis account, which gives credence to the idea that they are more than just physical objects.

docs.title: Boaz (kinsman redeemer of Ruth, from Bethlehem)
docs.text: Boaz was a wealthy landowner in Bethlehem and a prominent figure in the Book of Ruth. He is the son of Salmon and Rahab, and becomes the husband of Ruth. Boaz is the great-grandfather of King David and is mentioned in the genealogy of person/jesus in Matthew 1:5-6.

docs.title: Associations
docs.text:
• Associated with field (Ruth 2:3), drinking (Ruth 3:7, 1), wing (Ruth 3:9, 2), will not rest (Ruth 3:18), city gate (Ruth 4:1)
  • Child of Salmon (Matthew 1:5, Ruth 4:21), Rahab (Matthew 1:5)
  • Example of hospitality (Ruth 2:14)
  • Gave-to Ruth (Ruth 2:14)
  • Married to Ruth (Matthew 1:5, Ruth 4:13)
  • Member of tribe of Judah (Ruth 2:1)
  • Parent of Obed (Ruth 4:17, Ruth 4:21)
  • Resident of Bethlehem (Ruth 2:1)
  • Role as redeemer (Ruth 2:20, Ruth 3:9)
  • Visited Bethlehem (Ruth 2:4)

  1. "And Boaz drank and ate until his heart was good" is an idiom for getting drunk. Boaz celebrated with the reapers, had a lot to drink, and made good choices (Robert Whiting, 2025). ↩

  2. Boaz says in 2:1 "May Yahweh reward your work and may a full reward be given to you from Yahweh, the God of Israel, under whose wings you came to take refuge" and in 3:9, Ruth asks him to "Spread your wing over your servant because you are a redeemer." This is likely an allusion to Ruth taking refuge under the wings of God, and Boaz is being asked to symbolically do the same by spreading his "wing" (sometimes translated garment) over her. This is a culturally significant gesture indicating protection and care, akin to the way God protects His people (Robert Whiting, 2025). ↩

docs.title: David (son of Jesse)
docs.text: David, the youngest son of Jesse from the tribe of Judah, rose from humble beginnings as a shepherd to become the second king of Israel, succeeding Saul. He is known for his military prowess, his poetic abilities (attributed as the author of many Psalms), and his complex personal life, which included significant moral failures but also deep repentance.

docs.title: Associations
docs.text: • Child of Jesse (Ruth 4:22)

docs.title: Elimelech (husband of Naomi)
docs.text: Elimelech was a man from Bethlehem in Judah who, during a time of famine, moved his family to the land of Moab. He is the husband of Naomi and the father of two sons, Mahlon and Kilion. The family faced many challenges in Moab, including the deaths of Elimelech and his sons.

docs.title: Associations
docs.text:
• Died in Moab (Ruth 1:3)
  • Married to Naomi (Ruth 1:1-2)
  • Member of Ephrathite (Ruth 1:2)
  • Mentioned with plague (Ruth 1:1)
  • Parent of Mahlon (Ruth 1:2), Kilion (Ruth 1:2)
  • Related to Boaz (Ruth 2:1), Elimelech's Redeemer (Ruth 3:12)
  • Resident of Bethlehem (Ruth 1:1-2)
  • Visited Moab (Ruth 1:1)

docs.title: Elimelech's Redeemer (Unnamed kinsman-redeemer of Ruth, Naomi, Elimelech)
docs.text: The unnamed kinsman-redeemer of Elimelech, Naomi, and Ruth, who had the first right to redeem Elimelech's land and marry Ruth according to the custom of levirate marriage. He ultimately declines to do so, allowing Boaz to fulfill this role instead.

docs.text:

  • Role as redeemer (Ruth 4:1)

  1. The redeemer of whom Boaz had spoken is not named, but he is likely a close relative of Elimelech, possibly a brother or cousin. He has the first right of right/responsibility of redeem the land and marry Ruth according to the custom of levirate marriage (Robert Whiting, 2025). ↩

  2. The "unsandaled one" is a reference to Leviticus 25:9, "she shall pull off his sandal from his foot, and she shall spit in his face," which describes a shameful practice where the kinsman-redeemer is publicly humiliated, apparently it had been normalized by this time into an accepted cultural practice (Robert Whiting, 2025). ↩

docs.title: Hezron (son of Perez)
docs.text: Hezron was the son of Perez and the grandson of Judah, making him a descendant of Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob. He is an important figure in the genealogies of the Bible, as he is an ancestor of King David and, according to Christian tradition, Jesus Christ. He lived during the period of the Judges and is mentioned in the genealogies found in the books of Ruth and 1 Chronicles.

docs.title: Associations
docs.text:
• Child of Perez (Ruth 4:18)
  • Parent of Ram (Ruth 4:19)

docs.title: Jesse (son of Obed)
docs.text: Jesse was the son of Obed and the father of King David. He was a member of the tribe of Judah and lived in Bethlehem. Jesse is notable for being the grandfather of King Solomon and an ancestor of Jesus Christ according to the genealogies presented in the Bible.

docs.title: Associations
docs.text:
• Child of Obed (Ruth 4:17, Ruth 4:22)
  • Parent of David (Ruth 4:22)

docs.title: Judah (son of Jacob)
docs.text: Judah was the fourth son of Jacob and Leah, and his descendants formed the tribe of Judah, one of the twelve tribes of Israel. He is a significant figure in the biblical narrative, known for his role in the story of Joseph and for being an ancestor of King David and, according to Christian tradition, Jesus Christ.

docs.title: Associations
docs.text:
• Associated with Ruth (Ruth 4:12)
  • Married to Tamar (Ruth 4:12)
  • Parent of Perez (Ruth 4:12)

docs.title: Leah (first wife of Jacob)
docs.text: Leah was the first wife of Jacob and the mother of six of his twelve sons, who became the ancestors of six of the twelve tribes of Israel. She was the daughter of Laban and the older sister of Rachel. Leah's story is one of love, rivalry, and faithfulness, as she bore children to Jacob while Rachel, whom he loved more, remained barren for a time. Despite the challenges she faced, Leah is remembered for her significant role in the lineage of the Israelite people, particularly as the mother of Judah, from whom the Davidic line would come.

docs.title: Associations
docs.text: • Associated with Ruth (Ruth 4:11)

docs.title: Mara (Naomi name matches Mara)
docs.text: Mara is the name that Naomi adopts for herself after experiencing great personal loss. The name "Mara" means "bitter" in Hebrew, reflecting her feelings of sorrow and hardship following the deaths of her husband Elimelech and her two sons, Mahlon and Kilion. Naomi's choice to call herself Mara signifies her deep grief and the challenges she faces as a widow in a foreign land. Despite this, the story of Naomi and her daughter-in-law Ruth ultimately leads to redemption and hope, as Ruth's loyalty and faithfulness result in their restoration and inclusion in the lineage of King David.

docs.title: Naomi (mother in law of Ruth)
docs.text: Naomi was the wife of Elimelech and the mother-in-law of Ruth. She was originally from Bethlehem in Judah but moved to Moab with her husband and two sons during a time of famine. After the deaths of her husband and sons, Naomi decided to return to Bethlehem. Her story is one of loss, faith, and redemption, as she encourages Ruth to stay with her and ultimately finds hope through Ruth's marriage to Boaz, which leads to their inclusion in the lineage of King David.

  • Related to Elimelech's Redeemer (Ruth 3:12)
  • Resident of Bethlehem (Ruth 1:19)
  • Visited Moab (Ruth 1:1)

docs.title: Obed (son of Ruth)
docs.text: Obed was the son of Ruth and Boaz, making him a significant figure in the lineage of King David. He was born in Bethlehem after Ruth, a Moabite widow, married Boaz, a wealthy landowner from the tribe of Judah. Obed is notable for being the grandfather of King David, one of the most important figures in the Bible.

docs.title: Orpah (daughter-in-law of Naomi)
docs.text: Orpah was the daughter-in-law of Naomi and the wife of Kilion, one of Naomi's two sons. After the death of her husband, Orpah chose to return to her people in Moab rather than accompany Naomi back to Bethlehem. Her decision contrasts with that of her sister-in-law Ruth, who remained loyal to Naomi and became an ancestor of King David.

docs.title: Perez (son of Judah and Tamar)
docs.text: Perez was the son of Judah and Tamar, making him an important figure in the lineage of King David. His birth is notable because it occurred under unusual circumstances, as Tamar disguised herself as a prostitute to seduce Judah after he failed to fulfill his duty to provide her with a husband from his family. Perez is recognized as an ancestor of King David and, according to Christian tradition, Jesus Christ.

docs.title: Associations
docs.text:
• Associated with Ruth (Ruth 4:12)
  • Child of Tamar (Ruth 4:12), Judah (Ruth 4:12)
  • Parent of Hezron (Ruth 4:18)

docs.title: Rachel (favored wife of Jacob)
docs.text: Rachel was the favored wife of Jacob and the mother of Joseph and Benjamin, two of the twelve tribes of Israel. She is known for her beauty and for being the beloved wife of Jacob, who worked many years to marry her. Rachel's story is one of love, rivalry, and motherhood, as she struggled with infertility while her sister Leah bore many children.

docs.text: • Associated with Ruth (Ruth 4:11)

docs.title: Rahab (prostitute from Jericho)
docs.text: Rahab was a tribe/canaan woman in place/jericho who hid the tribe/israel spies sent by person/joshua. Because of her actions, she and her family were spared during the conquest of the city.1 She is later mentioned in the genealogy of Jesus in Matthew 1:5 and praised for her faith in Hebrews 11:31. Scholars note that she should not be confused with the creature/rahab_monster mentioned in Psalm 89:10 and Job 26:12. Rahab's story bridges the Old and New Testaments. Some extra-biblical sources, like Josephus2, recount her story in a similar way to Joshua 2. Her inclusion among women in person/jesus' genealogy is notable and discussed in multiple commentaries. Scholarly debate exists on the historical versus symbolic elements of her story.

docs.title: Associations
docs.text:
• Ancestor of person/jesus (Matthew 1:5, 4)
  • Assisted tribe/israel (Joshua 2), group/israelite_spies (Joshua 2)
  • Example of theme/faith (Hebrews 11:31, James 2:25)
  • Married to Salmon (Matthew 1:5)
  • Member of tribe/canaanite (Joshua 2)
  • Name matches creature/rahab (Job 26:12, Psalm 89:10)
  • Parent of Boaz (Matthew 1:5)
  • Resident of place/jericho (Joshua 2, 3)

docs.title: Ram (son of Hezron)
docs.text: Ram was the son of Hezron and the father of Amminadab, making him an important figure in the genealogy of King David. He is part of the lineage that connects to the tribe of Judah, which plays a significant role in the history of Israel.

docs.title: Ruth (daughter-in-law of Naomi)
docs.text: Ruth is the Moabite daughter-in-law of Naomi. After the deaths of her husband and father-in-law, she chooses to stay with Naomi and return to Bethlehem. There, she gleans in the fields of Boaz, who later marries her. Ruth is the great-grandmother of King David and an ancestor of Jesus Christ. Her story is one of loyalty, faith, and divine providence as well as Gentile inclusion in the lineage of the Messiah.

docs.title: Associations
docs.text:
• Associated with Yahweh (Ruth 1:16), field (Ruth 2:3), bread (Ruth 2:14), wine vinegar (Ruth 2:14), grain (Ruth 2:14), barley (Ruth 2:17), wheat (Ruth 2:23), feet (Ruth 3:14, Ruth 3:7, 2), wing (Ruth 2:1, 3), worthy woman (Ruth 3:11), Rachel (Ruth 4:11), Leah (Ruth 4:11), Israelite (Ruth 4:11), Perez (Ruth 4:12), Ephrathah (Ruth 4:11), Bethlehem (Ruth 4:11), Tamar (Ruth 4:12), Judah (Ruth 4:12), Moabite (Ruth 1:4)
  • Child of Naomi (Ruth 1:2)
  • Example of leaving family (Ruth 2:11), humility (Ruth 2:13)
  • Married to Kilion (Ruth 1:4, 1), Boaz (Matthew 1:5, Ruth 4:13)
  • Member of Moabite (Ruth 1:4)
  • Parent of Obed (Ruth 4:13, Ruth 4:17, 4)
  • Related to Elimelech's Redeemer (Ruth 3:12)
  • Resident of Bethlehem (Ruth 1:19)
  • Role as foreigner (Ruth 2:10)

  1. 10 years of marriage without children may indicate infertility for both Orpah and Ruth (Robert Whiting, 2025). ↩

  2. "Opening the feet" is a euphemism for sexual relations. It is unclear what exactly Ruth did, but it was likely more than just uncovering his feet while he slept (Robert Whiting, 2025). ↩

  3. Boaz says in 2:1 "May Yahweh reward your work and may a full reward be given to you from Yahweh, the God of Israel, under whose wings you came to take refuge" and in 3:9, Ruth asks him to "Spread your wing over your servant because you are a redeemer." This is likely an allusion to Ruth taking refuge under the wings of God, and Boaz is being asked to symbolically do the same by spreading his "wing" (sometimes translated garment) over her. This is a culturally significant gesture indicating protection and care, akin to the way God protects His people (Robert Whiting, 2025). ↩

  4. "Yahweh enabled her to conceive" indicates that Ruth had difficulty conceiving and Yahweh overcame said difficulties (Robert Whiting, 2025). ↩

docs.title: Salmon (husband of Rahab)
docs.text: Salmon was a member of the tribe of tribe/judah and is noted in biblical genealogies as the husband of Rahab and the father of Boaz. He is mentioned in the genealogy of person/jesus in Matthew 1:4-5. Little else is known about Salmon, but his marriage to Rahab is significant in the biblical narrative, linking the story of the conquest of Jericho to the lineage of King David and Jesus.

docs.title: Associations
docs.text:
• Child of Nahshon (Matthew 1:5, Ruth 4:20)

docs.title: Tamar (mother of Perez)
docs.text: Tamar was the daughter-in-law of Judah and the mother of Perez and Zerah. After the death of her husband Er, who was Judah's firstborn son, Tamar was left childless. According to the custom of levirate marriage, she was supposed to marry her husband's brother, Onan, to produce offspring in Er's name. However, Onan refused to fulfill this duty and was subsequently killed by God. Judah then promised to give his youngest son, Shelah, to Tamar when he came of age, but he failed to do so. In response, Tamar disguised herself as a prostitute and seduced Judah, resulting in the birth of twins, Perez and Zerah. Perez is significant as an ancestor of King David and, according to Christian tradition, Jesus Christ.

docs.title: Bethlehem
docs.text: Bethlehem, also known as Bethlehem Ephrathah, is a significant town in biblical history. It is located in the region of Judah and is famously known as the birthplace of King David and, according to Christian tradition, Jesus Christ. Bethlehem is often associated with themes of humility and divine providence, as it was a small town chosen by God for these monumental events. The town is mentioned multiple times in the Bible, particularly in the books of Ruth, Samuel, and the Gospels.

• Associated with Ruth (Ruth 4:11), Elimelech (Ruth 1:1-2), Boaz (Ruth 2:1), Naomi (Ruth 1:19)

  • Name matches Ephrathah

docs.title: Judah (place in southern Israel)
docs.text: Judah geographically refers to the territory allocated to the tribe of Judah, one of the twelve tribes of Israel. It is located in the southern part of the country and is known for its significant historical and biblical events, including the reign of King David and the birthplace of Jesus Christ in Bethlehem, which is situated within its borders.

docs.title: Moab (ancient kingdom east of the Dead Sea)
docs.text: Moab was an ancient kingdom located east of the Dead Sea, in what is now modern-day Jordan. It was inhabited by the Moabites, who were descendants of Lot, the nephew of Abraham. The Moabites are frequently mentioned in the Bible, often in relation to the Israelites. The relationship between the two peoples was complex, marked by both conflict and cooperation. Notably, Ruth, the Moabite woman who became the great-grandmother of King David, is a key figure in this narrative, illustrating the intertwined destinies of the Moabites and Israelites.
